title: Best credit cards for groceries of August 2025
description: From cards that earn elevated cash back to those that provide travel rewards, we look at all the ways you can get more rewards for your grocery spending.
content:
The average American family spends about $500 per month on groceries, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics. That’s one of the biggest expenses for a family, accounting for almost 8% of yearly spending. So it makes sense to get rewards from grocery spending by using a credit card that earns bonus points or cash back on groceries.

There are many credit cards on the market that earn elevated rewards for grocery spending, but not all of them are created equal. For starters, some cards will earn rewards in the form of cash back, while others earn points that can be redeemed for travel or transferred to airlines and hotels. And the return on your spending can vary widely by card, up to an exceptional 6%.

But with a wide variety of cards from many issuers, how do you decide which one meets your particular needs and earns the most rewards? The good news is that the cards in our selection of the best cards for groceries are flexible enough to cover pretty much everybody, from single people to families with monthly grocery budgets in the thousands.

If you’re confident in your ability to meet your financial obligations, since credit cards are a means of paying later for what you are consuming now, then you should consider one of the cards in our lineup of the best cards for groceries. Check out our picks below, and why they made the cut.

And here’s a breakdown of why each of these cards is a good choice for your grocery spending or, in many cases, a great choice for spending in other categories too.

The Blue Cash Preferred is a solid credit card from American Express, whose main selling point is a stellar return on grocery shopping.

It earns 6% cash back at U.S. supermarkets on up to $6,000 per year, which is the best rate for grocery shopping out there. After you hit that $6,000 in grocery spending, the return drops to just 1%, but the average family spends more or less that amount on groceries a year. (Families with significantly higher grocery budgets may be better served by the American Express® Gold Card.)

The same high 6% cash back return applies to select U.S. streaming subscriptions, while purchases at U.S. gas stations and for transit (including taxis and ride-shares, parking, tolls, trains, buses and more) earn 3%. On everything else, it earns 1%. That cash back is received in the form of Reward Dollars, which can be redeemed as a statement credit or at Amazon checkout.

Another important feature of the card is the intro period of 12 months of zero interest on purchases and balance transfers (20.24%-29.24% variable APR thereafter), which makes it a good choice for people who need to carry a balance for a while.

The card does have an annual fee, but it’s a relatively moderate $95, and you don’t have to pay it in your first year. You can more than make up for that fee with the card’s $10 monthly statement credit, totaling $120 a year, on a subscription to Disney+, Hulu or ESPN+, which includes bundle subscriptions (enrollment required).

That credit helps cement the Blue Cash Preferred as a workhorse card for families with an average grocery budget and mainstream viewing habits; you could call it the all-American credit card. It’s not meant for people who travel often, much less for those who travel overseas, since it charges foreign transaction fees. But people who aren’t interested in travel rewards or benefits may find that it fills most or all of their needs in a credit card.

The Blue Cash Everyday is essentially a no-annual-fee version of the Blue Cash Preferred. They’re both American Express cards that earn cash back, but the Blue Cash Everyday earns 3% on U.S. supermarkets compared to 6%. Like with the Preferred, the elevated rate applies on up to $6,000 per year in purchases, then it drops to 1%. The Blue Cash Everyday earns 3% cash back on U.S. online retail purchases and U.S. gas stations, also on up to $6,000 per year, then 1%.

While the return on grocery spending may be less than its sibling card earns, the Everyday has a longer period with no interest, with 15 months at 0% APR on purchases and balance transfers (20.24%-29.24% variable APR thereafter). Its current welcome offer is slightly lower than the Preferred, with $200 in statement credits instead of $250, but you’ll earn it after spending $2,000 in the first six months, not $3,000.

If you watch streaming content, you’ll find the $7 monthly credit for a subscription to Disney+, Hulu or ESPN+, including bundle subscriptions, useful. Enrollment is required, but for that minor step, you get a $70 credit per year.

Overall, the Blue Cash Everyday offers a good value proposition, but if you spend enough, you may find the Blue Cash Preferred more rewarding despite its annual fee.

With an annual fee of $325 and elevated earnings on worldwide restaurants and airlines, as well as on groceries, the American Express Gold is aimed squarely at people who travel and eat out fairly frequently — and can justify paying that much.

Its most relevant feature is the 4x American Express Membership Rewards® Points it earns per dollar spent at U.S. supermarkets, up to $25,000 per calendar year (1x afterward). That means you can rack up four points per dollar on up to $2,083 in grocery spending per month, plenty for most budgets.

Beyond groceries, it earns 4x points at restaurants worldwide, up to $50,000 per calendar year (then 1x for the rest of the year). Flights booked directly with airlines or on the American Express travel portal earn 3x; to round out a card clearly designed for travelers, you’ll also earn 2x points on prepaid hotels and other eligible purchases booked on Amex Travel. On all other eligible purchases, the card earns 1x.

The card also offers several credits that, all together, are valued more than the annual fee but require some work to keep track of and may not be to everybody’s taste.

While some of those credits are relatively easy to use — such as the Resy credit, which is great for people who live in or travel to major cities with several Resy restaurants, or the straightforward Dunkin’ credit — others are exotic. Hotels in The Hotel Collection are decidedly upscale, for example, and you’d need to stay at least two nights to trigger the credit.

This card, however, isn’t aimed at consumers who prefer frugality. With its high annual fee and perks to go with it, it’s a very good choice for people who like to travel and dine out, or for those who have high grocery budgets and want high rewards for it.

The American Express Gold doesn’t earn cash back like the other Amex cards in this article either. it earns American Express points, which can be used for travel on the Amex portal or transferred to 20 partner airlines and hotels, including Delta Air Lines and JetBlue.

This versatile, no-annual-fee card is a strong performer when it comes to earning rewards not just on groceries.

It earns unlimited 3% cash back at grocery stores (excluding superstores like Walmart and Target) and adds 3% on dining, entertainment and streaming services. That alone would make it an attractive card, but the Capital One Savor Cash Rewards does better than that. It earns a spectacular 8% cash back on purchases through Capital One Entertainment, a portal where cardholders can buy tickets to sports, music and dining events. Then, the card also earns a respectable 5% on hotels, vacation rentals and rental cars booked through the Capital One Travel portal. On all other purchases, it earns 1%.

That’s a remarkable earning structure for a card with no annual fee, and it would be a good argument by itself for getting the Savor Cash Rewards — but you can get even more value from the card by pairing it with the Capital One Venture X Rewards Credit Card (which has a $395 annual fee) or another Venture card from Capital One with a lower annual fee. That way, you can transfer the cash back earned on the Savor card to the Venture card. You’ll get 1 Capital One mile for each cent transferred, and then you can redeem Capital One miles for statement credits or transfer them to Capital One’s 15-plus airline and hotel partners.

This can give you outsize value, since miles can be worth well over 1 cent each when transferred to travel partners. Capital One miles are worth 1.85 cents each, according to The Points Guy.

Notably for a card with no annual fee, the Savor Cash Rewards doesn’t charge extra for foreign transactions. This helps make it an exceptionally versatile performer, even for people who travel abroad.

You could earn more on dining out or on supermarkets with the American Express Gold, for example, but you would also have to pay a high annual fee.

This card is, quite literally, a jack-of-all-trades. It earns 2% cash back on everything you buy, every time, all the time. Its simplicity and elevated earning rate make it one of the best options for many people. Unlike credit cards that require you to track bonus categories or redeem points strategically for maximum value, the Citi Double Cash earns the same on every purchase, be it groceries or anything else. You’ll get 1% cash back when you buy and another 1% when you pay off those purchases. No frills, no fuss.

The lone exception to that general 2% earning rate is 5% cash back on hotels, car rentals and attractions booked on the Citi Travel® portal. If you book travel directly from providers, you’ll get 2%.

When you want to redeem the cash back, you have three options: a statement credit, direct deposit or a physical check. You can also transfer your ThankYou points to most of Citi’s travel partners at a 1:0.7 ratio.

Like most other cards with no annual fee, the Citi Double Cash does have one drawback: It charges foreign transaction fees, which are typically higher than the 2% cash back rate. But while it’s not a good choice to bring on a trip abroad, within the U.S., it offers a clear, straightforward and strong value proposition.

Many travel cards earn high returns for spending on travel categories but earn relatively poorly in other categories. That’s not the case with the Citi Strata Premier, a rare case of a travel rewards card that still earns a high rate on everyday spending. It could even be a single, do-it-all card for some frequent flyers.

The Citi Strata Premier earns an exceptional 10 points per dollar spent on hotels, car rentals and attractions booked on the Citi Travel portal, as well as a respectable 3x on flights and hotels booked directly with providers. It also earns 3x at restaurants, gas and EV charging stations, as well as 3x at supermarkets, which is why it’s a top groceries card for people who also value travel. On all other purchases, it earns just 1x point per dollar. You can overcome that shortcoming by pairing the Strata Premier with the Citi Double Cash, which earns 2% cash back on all purchases.

The card does come with an annual fee of $95, but we think it’s still a relative steal for people who need its flexibility. If you fly and/or leave the U.S. with some frequency, the Strata Premier could turn into a trusted companion.

Some cardholders could even offset the annual fee in one fell swoop by using the card’s $100 annual hotel benefit. Once per calendar year, you’ll receive $100 off a single hotel stay booked on Citi Travel and costing $500 or more (excluding taxes and fees). While this credit may not have the widest appeal, it could prove useful, for example, on a family vacation.

The Strata Premier isn’t perfect, though. Citi has a relatively small pool of transfer partners, with only two domestic airlines — American and JetBlue — making its American Express, Chase and Capital One rivals potentially more appealing to some travelers. Some competitors also define travel more broadly; with the Strata Premier, elevated travel earnings don’t apply to trains, transit and cruises, for example.

But with all that said, Citi’s mid-tier travel card still punches above its weight, for groceries and otherwise. With no foreign transaction fees, the Citi Strata Premier also travels well outside the U.S. Even better news? That elevated 3x earning rate applies to supermarkets abroad too.

This Chase-issued card makes sense for one group of people only, but for them, it’s perfect. If you’re a frequent shopper at Amazon, its subsidiary Whole Foods Market or Amazon Fresh, the Amazon Prime Visa rewards you with an unbeatable 5% cash back. On some rotating items and categories from Amazon, you’ll even earn 10% back.

You’ll also get 5% back on Chase Travel purchases and 2% at gas stations, restaurants and on local transit, including ride-sharing, as well as 1% on all other purchases.

The catch is that, while there’s no annual fee, you must have a $139-per-year Amazon Prime membership to get this card, but that’s an easy bar to clear since an estimated 180 million Americans are Prime members.

Another catch is that the cash back rewards from the card are worth a penny each, and that’s it. Points and cash back from other cards can be worth more, but there is a lot to be said for the simplicity of earning and redeeming with the Amazon Prime Visa. In fact, points from this card are the only points we like to use on Amazon.

The following FAQs have been answered by senior money editor and credit card expert Alberto Riva.

CNN Underscored’s team of expert editors and contributors carefully reviews credit cards, travel rewards and loyalty programs to help readers navigate changes and make informed financial decisions. For this story, senior money editor and credit card expert Alberto Riva, who holds several of the credit cards in this article, applied his years of industry knowledge and personal experience to ensure every detail is accurate and actionable. Our expert recommendations are grounded in real-world value, not hype, and backed by thorough analysis, expert insight and a commitment to clarity and transparency.

Opinions expressed here are the author’s alone, not those of any bank, credit card issuer, hotel, airline or other entity. This content has not been reviewed, approved or otherwise endorsed by any of the entities included within the article.

What are points and miles worth? TPG’s September 2025 monthly valuations
Editor's Note
Quick summary
- TPG provides updated valuations for major airline, hotel and transferable points programs.
- Valuations for some programs are determined using a data-driven methodology considering redemption rates, availability and program updates.
- The new Atmos Rewards program merges Alaska Airlines and Hawaiian Airlines loyalty schemes, offering flexible elite status earning and notable perks for top-tier members.
- Recent program changes, transfer partner updates and new redemption options may affect the value and flexibility of your points and miles.
What to consider
- Valuations can fluctuate based on program changes, availability and redemption options, so actual value may differ from published estimates.
- Some programs are undergoing transitions, such as Atmos Rewards.
- Transfer partner changes and other program changes may affect your ability to maximize rewards.
What you'll miss from the article
- A detailed breakdown of current point and mile values across major loyalty programs and insight into recent program updates that could impact your travel strategy.
Generated by AI with support from our editorial team.
One of the questions people often ask us is, "How much is a point or mile worth?"
The true answer varies from point to point and person to person. It also depends on your travel goals and how much you maximize a particular loyalty currency. Still, some rewards are worth more than others, and our goal is to give you a sense of how they stack up.
Historically, TPG has valued points and miles based on a combination of factors: the price at which we would purchase the points or miles, award costs in the program (factoring in availability and fees), and our expertise in the program's inner workings. However, we now use extensive data for the top seven U.S. airline loyalty programs to better estimate the value you should aim to get from your rewards. Read our explainer post on our data-driven valuations for a full methodology breakdown.

Top points and miles news
August's biggest travel loyalty news was the unveiling of Atmos Rewards, the exciting and long-awaited new joint loyalty program between Alaska Airlines and Hawaiian Airlines. This program merges Mileage Plan and HawaiianMiles. Balances will convert at a 1:1 ratio Oct. 1, creating a single points ecosystem across both carriers.
The new program offers some unique and impressively rewarding benefits. For example, members will be able to choose whether they earn points and status points based on distance, revenue or segments. This flexibility, launching in 2026, could make Atmos Rewards one of the most passenger-friendly airline programs for earning elite status. You'll still be able to earn elite status from award travel, too.
Alaska is giving its top-tier Atmos Titanium elite members a great new perk: free day-of-departure upgrades into global business class — and they can even bring a companion along. No points, no certificates, just an automatic benefit. While it's common to see U.S. loyalty programs upgrade their top-tier elite members on domestic flights, this perk applies to all Alaska and Hawaiian flights.
Credit cards were refreshed under the new Atmos Rewards brand, and the new Atmos™ Rewards Summit Visa Infinite® Credit Card offers 100,000 bonus Atmos Rewards points and a 25,000-point Global Companion Award after you spend $6,000 or more on purchases within the first 90 days after account opening. It also offers 10,000 status points on every card anniversary, a faster path to elite status and an astonishing 3 points per dollar spent on foreign transactions, which makes it a great option for international travelers.
Finally, Alaska's industry-leading partner redemption rates are staying. Brett Catlin, Alaska's loyalty chief, told TPG ahead of the Atmos Rewards launch, "We're really happy with where our redemptions are at, particularly on the partner side. We have no plans at this point to radically change how we're structuring redemptions." This being said, Alaska is making some updates to its chart to account for new long-haul Alaska and Hawaiian flights.
Related: Are we all (mostly) winners? My take on Alaska's new unified Atmos Rewards program
Top offers for earning points and miles in September
Here are some of the other best options this month if you're looking for a new travel rewards card that earns transferable points or miles.
Chase Sapphire Reserve
The Chase Sapphire Reserve® (see rates and fees) currently offers 125,000 bonus points after you spend $6,000 on purchases in the first three months from account opening.
The recently refreshed card has updated earning rates, including 8 points per dollar spent on purchases through Chase Travel℠ (including The Edit hotel bookings), 4 points per dollar spent on flights booked directly and 4 points per dollar spent on hotels booked directly. The new annual fee is $795, but cardholders will get up to $500 in statement credits for hotel bookings made with The Edit each calendar year ($250 in credits biannually on prepaid bookings with The Edit of two or more nights), up to $300 in statement credits each calendar year for dining at restaurants that are part of Sapphire Reserve Exclusive Tables ($150 in credits biannually) and more.
Check out our Chase Sapphire Reserve card review to learn more.
Official application link: Chase Sapphire Reserve
Chase Sapphire Reserve for Business
Chase recently unveiled a brand-new business card, the Chase Sapphire Reserve for Business℠ (see rates and fees). This card has a massive welcome offer of 200,000 bonus points after you spend $30,000 on purchases in your first six months from account opening.
This product earns 8 points per dollar spent on purchases through Chase Travel (including The Edit), 4 points per dollar spent on flights and hotels booked directly, and 3 points per dollar spent on social media and search engine advertising. It comes with multiple flexible statement credits but has a $795 annual fee. See our Sapphire Reserve for Business card review for more information.
Official application link: Chase Sapphire Reserve for Business
Capital One Venture X Rewards Credit Card
The Capital One Venture X Rewards Credit Card is a compelling option due to its great earning rates and included perks. The card currently has a welcome offer of 75,000 bonus miles after you spend $4,000 on purchases within the first three months from account opening.
You'll earn at least 2 miles per dollar spent on purchases and get access to various useful benefits, including a $300 annual credit for bookings through Capital One Travel, 10,000 bonus miles each account anniversary and complimentary access to Capital One airport lounges.
Check out our Capital One Venture X Rewards card review for more details.
Learn more: Capital One Venture X Rewards Credit Card
Capital One Venture Rewards Credit Card
The Capital One Venture Rewards Credit Card offers 75,000 bonus miles after you spend $4,000 on purchases within the first three months from account opening. The annual fee for the Capital One Venture card is $95 — a reasonable amount for a card with such a generous welcome offer.
See our Capital One Venture Rewards card review for more details.
Learn more: Capital One Venture Rewards Credit Card
The Platinum Card from American Express
With the The Platinum Card® from American Express, you can find out your offer and see if you are eligible for as high as 175,000 Membership Rewards points after spending $8,000 on purchases in the first six months of card membership. Welcome offers vary, and you may not be eligible for an offer.
Our valuations peg these points at up to $3,500 based on the value you can get when leveraging the Membership Rewards transfer partners. The Amex Platinum is packed with benefits, so read our Amex Platinum review for all the details. The Amex Platinum has a $695 annual fee (see rates and fees).
Official application link: The Platinum Card from American Express
American Express Gold Card
One of the most popular cards with TPG staffers, the American Express® Gold Card lets new cardholders find out their offer and see if they are eligible for as high as 100,000 Membership Rewards points after they spend $6,000 on purchases within the first six months of card membership. Welcome offers vary, and you may not be eligible for an offer.
The Amex Gold is great for many everyday purchases. You'll earn 4 points per dollar spent on groceries at U.S. supermarkets (on up to $25,000 in purchases per calendar year, then 1 point per dollar spent) and 4 points per dollar spent at restaurants worldwide (on up to $50,000 in purchases per calendar year, then 1 point per dollar spent). The card has a $325 annual fee (see rates and fees), so check out our Amex Gold review to see whether it makes sense.
Official application link: American Express Gold Card
Ink Business Preferred Credit Card
The Ink Business Preferred® Credit Card (see rates and fees) has a welcome offer of 90,000 bonus points after you spend $8,000 on purchases in the first three months after card opening.
The Ink Business Preferred offers 3 points per dollar spent on the first $150,000 spent on travel and select business categories each account anniversary year. For more details, check out our Ink Business Preferred Credit Card review.
Official application link: Ink Business Preferred Credit Card

2X Membership Rewards® Points
Membership Rewards-enrolled Card Members get at least 1 Membership Rewards® point for every eligible dollar spent on their Membership Rewards program-enrolled American Express® Card. Those same Card Members will also get at least 1 additional point for each dollar of eligible travel purchases made on amextravel.com on their Membership Rewards program-enrolled American Express Card. Corporate Card Members are not eligible for the additional point. Eligible travel purchases include all travel purchases made with your Membership Rewards program-enrolled American Express® Card on amextravel.com, including air, prepaid hotels, prepaid short-term rentals, prepaid car rentals, vacation packages (flight + hotel packages) or cruise reservations, minus returns and other credits. Platinum and Business Platinum Card Members are only eligible for 1 additional point on cruise reservations. Eligible travel purchases do NOT include non-prepaid car rentals, non-prepaid hotels, ticketing service or other fees, or interest charges. Additional point bonuses you may receive with your Card on other purchase categories from American Express may not be combined with this offer (e.g., 5X bonuses for Platinum and Business Platinum Card Members, 3X bonuses for Business Gold Card Members, 2X bonus on your first $50,000 in purchases for Blue Business Plus Card Members or 1.5X bonuses for Business Centurion and Business Platinum Card Members, etc.). Any portion of a charge that you elect to cover through redemption of Membership Rewards points is not eligible to receive points. Additional points will be credited to the Membership Rewards account 10-12 weeks after final payment is made.
3X Membership Rewards Points Business Gold
Basic American Express® Business Gold Card Members will get at least one Membership Rewards® point for each dollar of eligible travel purchases on their Card and on any Employee Cards on their Card Account. Basic Card Members will get 2 additional points (for a total of 3 points) for each dollar spent on eligible travel purchases on their Business Gold Card Account from American Express. Eligible travel purchases include scheduled flights and prepaid flight+hotel packages made online at AmexTravel.com, minus returns and other credits. Additionally, eligible travel purchases include prepaid hotel purchases made through American Express Travel over the phone with our Travel Consultants or made online at AmexTravel.com, minus returns and other credits. Eligible travel purchases do NOT include non-prepaid hotel bookings, scheduled flights and prepaid flight+hotel packages booked over the phone, vacation packages, car rentals, cruise, hotel group reservations or events, ticketing service, cancellation or other fees, interest charges, purchases of travelers checks, purchases or reloading of prepaid cards, or purchases of other cash equivalents. To be eligible for the 3X Membership Rewards® points, the booking must be both reserved and charged on the Basic or Additional/Employee Card on the Card Account. To modify a reservation, you can cancel and rebook your reservation on AmexTravel.com or by calling a representative of AmexTravel.com at 1-800-297-2977. To be eligible for the 3X Membership Rewards® points, any changes to an existing reservation must be made through the same method as your original booking.
